Aquaponics: Aquaponics is a sustainable method of farming that combines aquaculture and hydroponics. Fish are raised in a controlled environment and their waste provides nutrients for the plants. This method can be set up in urban areas and can provide a source of food for a family.

Foraging: Foraging for wild edible plants and mushrooms can be a sustainable way to feed oneself. This method requires knowledge of local flora and fauna, as well as the ability to identify edible plants.

Permaculture: Permaculture is a system of agricultural and social design principles centered around simulating or directly utilizing the patterns and features observed in natural ecosystems. This method can be used to create sustainable food systems in a variety of environments.

Local food co-ops: Joining a local food co-op can provide access to fresh, locally grown produce. These co-ops often prioritize sustainable farming practices and can be a reliable source of food in the absence of traditional farming.

Community supported agriculture (CSA): CSA is a system where individuals purchase a share in a farm and receive a portion of the farm's harvest. This can be a sustainable way to access fresh, locally grown produce.
